headline: Authentic Chicken Adobo
description: Adobo is a simple and hearty Filipino dish. In this version, chicken is marinated in vinegar and soy sauce, then slowly cooked with garlic and spices. Serve over steamed white rice.

video.description: Learn how to make authentic Filipino-style chicken adobo.
video.name: Authentic Filipino Chicken Adobo - Welcome World Cuisine

name: Authentic Chicken Adobo
recipeIngredient: 1 head garlic, peeled and coarsely chopped
1 head garlic, peeled and coarsely chopped

recipeInstructions.text: Combine vinegar, soy sauce,1 head garlic, bay leaves, garlic powder, black pepper, and 1 1/2 teaspoons annatto powder in a large bowl. Add chicken, stir to coat with marinade, cover, and refrigerate for at least 4 hours.
Remove chicken from the marinade and pat dry. Reserve the marinade.
Heat 2 tablespoons vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Cook chicken in the hot oil until browned, about 4 minutes per side. Remove skillet from heat.
Heat 1 tablespoon vegetable oil in a small skillet over medium heat. Cook and stir 1 head garlic until browned, about 3 minutes. Add 1 1/2 teaspoons annatto powder; simmer for 3 minutes.

Pour annatto mixture over chicken and add reserved marinade. Bring to a simmer, cover, and cook until chicken is tender, about 45 minutes. Uncover and cook until sauce has reduced slightly, about 10 minutes.

review.reviewBody: it was delicious! and healthy for those how to take some extra taste in life i am from Pakistan and i have recipe site you can visit them and see quality recipe of chicken
Just a firsr try. Everyone including myself loved it
My family really enjoyed this dish and we have tried many versions. We just used regular vinegar because that’s all I had. Good!

This is my second time making it. The first time I didn't have annatto powder so I subbed for sweet blend tumeric (it has lots of cinnamon in it which added a special magic to the flavor and not to mention it made it smell even better, if you can believe that) and paprika. This time around I found annatto powder and I still added the sweet blend tumeric because I couldn't live without it. Absolutely wonderful and it was an instant hit at home. Thank you. :)
I substituted cider vinegar and also add freash Ginger
Easy to make and tastes awesome thank you!God bless
It was a great success! I substitute with Apple cider vinegar and this gave it a great deal of flavor. Also substituted coriander and turmeric for some of the annato.
My husband enjoyed this more than I did. The vinegar marinade was a bit to strong for me.
Love this recipe. I don’t think a thing should be changed
I followed the recipe exactly and the chicken was tender but my family didn't love the flavor.

Great recipe! Yes, the annatto and garlic are listed twice, because they are used twice...SMH. McCormick now has ground annatto (Achiote Molido), so it's a little easier to find in larger grocery stores. The second time I made it I used reduced sodium soy sauce, and it definitely cut down on the saltiness from when I originally tried the recipe but kept the same great flavor. This one's a keeper!

I am making this recipe for the second time. It's great! Since annatto is a coloring (and I couldn't find it), I substituted a little turmeric. Last time I made it with chicken, this time I mixed pork and chicken and used a slow cooker. It was also wonderful! Since you end up with a ton of sauce, I thickened it with cornstarch at the very end and served it over UNSALTED rice. The sauce is quite salty (guess you could use low-salt soy). It's a very satisfying dish with flavor combinations I am familiar with in marinades but yet, with the vinegar, it turns out to be a very different taste experience...one that we loved! Oh...I wish I could find coconut vinegar but read other adobo recipes and used apple cider vinegar; again, delicious.
MissiFizzle...the garlic and annatto powder are SUPPOSED to be listed twice, you ADD more after you brown the chicken!! Maybe then it would be a 5 star recipe, a lot more flavor!!
FYI... garlic and annatto powder are both listed twice
